entry.title: Re: Tax mismatch in accounting and billing document due t...
entry.content:
Try with the below approach

In FTXP, have a tax code for the current tax percent for ZD1 shown below, which should be exclusive to handle down payments. In vk11, maintain the tax condition type with tax code for the given specific period. In v/06, create a new condition type and set this as statistical in your pricing procedure. In ob40, ensure, this tax code is assigned to an Account Key which is specific to down payment and related G/L Account.

With the above, your pricing procedure should be

AZWR and ZTXD must be statistical to prevent tax recalculation on cleared amount

entry.title: Re: FI313 in FX Valuation
entry.content: For information, FMTFDERIVE is used to generate technical clearing lines (DR/CR) for specific internal order types. These lines are not part of the original posting but are added for statistical or balancing purposes. When FX Valuation runs, it processes all open items, including those added by FMTFDERIVE. These technical lines lack Process and Event fields, so FMDERIVE cannot apply rules, resulting to FI313 error — no Funds Center derived. In order to overcome from this, what you can do is add a fallback rule in FMDERIVE that, if Process/Event is blank or unknown, derive a default Funds Center based on internal order or cost object. This ensures valuation lines don’t fail even if they’re technically generated.

entry.title: Re: In the scope item 5D2,IC Supplier Invoice (SIIC) erro...
entry.content:
Hello @omega-ou 

Thank you for your question.

The error you are experiencing in the IC Supplier Invoice process of scope item 5D2 is a common SAP localization and tax configuration issue and it especially happens in cross-country transactions. The error you are experiencing is because the Place of supply is mandatory in Indian GST scenarios and the reasons is, tax determination depends on location of supplier, customer, and factory or shipment. Also note, if your master data is not properly configured, SAP cannot derive the place of supply automatically.

My advice is to consider a doing the following to enable you resolve that issue:

First, make sure your tax procedure for India is correctly set in your company code settings for the sales org, purchasing org, and plant. It is essential to ensure that the relevant tax jurisdiction codes and place of supply fields are maintained for both the India sales company and the China plant/business partner.

Secondly, make sure your Business Partner and Plant Master Data are correctly configured. They should have proper GST Registration Number, Place of Supply must be correct, and Tax Classification must be correctly assigned. Also note, the addresses should be up to date with their correct state or region. The reason is, SAP uses them determine the place of supply.

Finally, in your customizing and field mapping, ensure that the cross-border scenarios maintain correct ship-to and bill-to details that reflect actual transaction locations. You can review your configuration under SPRO à Materials Management à Purchasing à Taxes à Define Tax Determination Rules.

Consult the below SAP localization note reference for more details.

3554277 

3509454 Place of supply is not determined

I hope this provides the desired insights.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Chart of Accounts Selection
entry.content:
Background:
All company codes are presently operated in the PCE system. Several overseas company codes are to be migrated to the new ES landscape. Consolidation continues to be executed at group level under one single operative chart of accounts (CoA). The group consolidation is therefore based on this operative CoA.
Issue:
The ES system was delivered with SAP Best-Practice chart of accounts. The delivered Best-Practice CoA deviates significantly from the client’s current operative CoA. We have to decide which CoA will be used in ES.
Key question – ES project view:
Which alternative is preferable without endangering the group consolidation?
Adopt the SAP Best-Practice operative CoA in ES, or
Re-use the client’s current operative CoA in ES?
If we adopt the SAP Best-Practice CoA:
Which system settings (e.g. mapping of group CoA, consolidation staging area, flexible upload, elimination rules, etc.) are required to guarantee that the group consolidation remains unchanged?
If we keep the client’s current operative CoA:
Does SAP provide a mass-maintenance tool to create the operative CoA in ES

Your expert advice is appreciated.

entry.title: Unmanaged RAP — Deep Insert, CUD Operations & Action Handling
entry.content:
When developing Fiori Elements applications with the ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model (RAP), one of the key decisions is whether to go with Managed or Unmanaged implementation. In this blog, I’ll walk you through building a Fiori Elements app using Unmanaged RAP.

Unlike the managed scenario—where RAP automatically handles persistence and standard operations—Unmanaged RAP gives the developer full control over database interactions. This flexibility is especially useful when you need to handle complex business requirements such as:

  • Performing deep inserts, for example creating a main entity along with its related child entities in one request.
  • Having fine-grained control over create, update, and delete logic.
  • Defining custom actions tailored to specific business needs.

Another key concept here is RAP’s Logical Unit of Work (LUW). All changes are executed in a transactional way and only committed after validation checks pass. This ensures data consistency and is one of the main reasons why unmanaged RAP is often chosen in scenarios requiring complex persistence logic.

What we will be doing?

In this exercise, we will build an Unmanaged RAP app to create and modify records for a main entity along with its related child entities and Custom Action

By the end of this exercise, our List Report Page and Object Page will have the following capabilities and layout:

  • Deep Insert: Handle a main entity with related child entities in a single transaction.
  • Full CRUD: Create, Read, Update, and Delete operations on both main and child entities, fully controlled by the developer.
  • Association Handling: Use Create-by-Association (CBA) and Read-by-Association (RBA) for managing child entities in the Object Page.
  • Custom Actions: Define business-specific actions that update both main and related entities.

We will be creating following objects –

  • Interface View
  • Projection View
  • Metadata Extension
  • Behavior Definition
  • Behavior Projection
  • Implementation Class
  • Service Definition
  • Service Binding

Steps to create unmanaged scenario based app

1) Interface Views :

    Parent CDS view : 

@AbapCatalog.viewEnhancementCategory: [#NONE]
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'Interface view for Bookings'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
define root view entity ZI_FlightBooking  as select from zbooking_hdr
composition [1..*] of  ZI_BookingPassenger as _Passengers
{
  key booking_id,
      customer_id,
      flight_no,
      booking_date,
      status,
      _Passengers
}

 

Child View :

@AbapCatalog.viewEnhancementCategory: [#NONE]
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'interface view for booking passengers'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
define view entity ZI_BookingPassenger
  as select from zbooking_pass as _Passengers
  association to parent ZI_FlightBooking as _Flightbooking on $projection.booking_id = _Flightbooking.booking_id

{
  key booking_id,
  key passenger_no,
      name,
      seat_no,
      ticket_status,
      _Flightbooking
}

 Explanation:

The parent view ZI_FlightBooking represents the main booking entity, while the child view ZI_BookingPassenger represents the passengers associated with each booking. The child view has a direct association back to the parent, linking each passenger to its corresponding booking. This relationship allows the application to display and manage bookings together with their related passengers.

2) Projection Views : 

@AbapCatalog.viewEnhancementCategory: [#NONE]
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@VDM.viewType: #CONSUMPTION
@Metadata.allowExtensions: true
@EndUserText.label: 'Consumption view for flight bookings'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
define root view entity ZC_FlightBooking 
  provider contract transactional_query
  as projection on ZI_FlightBooking as _FlightBookings
{
  key booking_id,
  customer_id,
  flight_no,
  booking_date,
  status,
  /* Associations */
  _Passengers : redirected to composition child ZC_BOOKINGPASSENGER 
  
  
}
@AbapCatalog.viewEnhancementCategory: [#NONE]
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'Consumption for flight bookings passengers'
@VDM.viewType: #CONSUMPTION
@Metadata.allowExtensions: true
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
define view entity ZC_BOOKINGPASSENGER 
  as projection on ZI_BookingPassenger
{
  key booking_id,
  key passenger_no,
  name,
  seat_no,
  ticket_status,
  /* Associations */
  _Flightbooking :  redirected to parent ZC_FlightBooking
  
  
}

 

3) Metadata Extensions :

@Metadata.layer: #CORE
@UI: {
   headerInfo: {
     typeName: 'Flight Booking',
     typeNamePlural: 'FLight Bookings',
     title:       { value: 'booking_id' },
     description: { value: 'flight_no' }
   }
 }
@Search.searchable: true
annotate entity ZC_FlightBooking with
{
  .facet: [

    {
       id               : 'Passengers',
       label            : 'Passengers Details',
       type             : #LINEITEM_REFERENCE,
       position         : 20,
       targetElement    : '_Passengers'
      },


      {
        id: 'Flight',
        purpose: #STANDARD,
        position: 10,
        label: 'Flight Details',
        type: #IDENTIFICATION_REFERENCE
    }
    ]


  : {
    lineItem:       [ { position: 10, importance: #HIGH } ,
   { type: #FOR_ACTION , dataAction: 'ConfirmTicket', label: 'CONFIRM', position: 60  } ],
    identification: [ { position: 10 }
   ]
  }
  .selectionField: [ { position: 10 } ]
  .defaultSearchElement: true
  .fieldGroup: [{ qualifier: 'fgHeader' , position: 10 }]
  booking_id;

  : {
    lineItem:       [ { position: 20, importance: #HIGH } ],
   identification: [ { position: 20 } ]
  }
  .selectionField: [ { position: 20 } ]
  .defaultSearchElement: true
  .fieldGroup: [{ qualifier: 'fgHeader' , position: 20 }]
  customer_id;

  : {
   lineItem:       [ { position: 30, importance: #HIGH } ] ,
   identification: [ { position: 30 } ]  }

  .defaultSearchElement: true
  @EndUserText.label:'Flight Number'
  .selectionField: [ { position: 30 } ]
  flight_no;

  : {
    lineItem:       [ { position: 40, importance: #HIGH } ]
  }
  .defaultSearchElement: true
  .selectionField: [ { position: 40 } ]
  @EndUserText.label:'Booking Date'
  .fieldGroup: [{ qualifier: 'fgHeader' , position: 40 }]
  booking_date;

  : {
    lineItem:       [ { position: 50, importance: #HIGH } ],
    identification: [ { position: 50 } ]
  }
  .selectionField: [ { position: 50 } ]
  .defaultSearchElement: true
  @EndUserText.label:'Status'
  status;

}
@Metadata.layer: #CORE
annotate entity ZC_BOOKINGPASSENGER
  with 
{

  : { lineItem: [ { position: 10, importance: #HIGH } ] }
  .identification: [{ position: 10 }]
  passenger_no;
  : { lineItem: [ { position: 20, importance: #HIGH } ]}
  .identification: [{ position: 20 }]
  name;
  : { lineItem: [ { position: 30, importance: #HIGH } ] }
  seat_no;
  : { lineItem: [ { position: 40, importance: #HIGH } ] }
  ticket_status;

}

4) Behavior Definition :

unmanaged implementation in class zbp_i_flightbooking unique;
strict ( 2 );

define behavior for ZI_FlightBooking //alias <alias_name>
//late numbering
lock master
authorization master ( instance )
//etag master <field_name>
{
  create ( authorization : global );
  update;
  delete;
 field ( readonly ) booking_id;
  association _Passengers { create; }
  action ConfirmTicket result [1] $self;
}

define behavior for ZI_BookingPassenger //alias <alias_name>
//late numbering
lock dependent by _Flightbooking
authorization dependent by _Flightbooking
//etag master <field_name>
{
  create ;
  update;
  delete;
 field ( readonly ) booking_id;
  association _Flightbooking;
}

5) Behavior Projection

projection;
strict ( 2 );

define behavior for ZC_FlightBooking //alias <alias_name>
{
  use create;
  use update;
  use delete;


use association _Passengers  { create ; }
use action ConfirmTicket;
}

define behavior for ZC_BOOKINGPASSENGER //alias <alias_name>


{

 use create ;
  use update;
  use delete;
  use association _Flightbooking ;
}

 

6) Implementation Class :

CLASS lhc_ZI_FlightBooking DEFINITION INHERITING FROM cl_abap_behavior_handler.
  PRIVATE SECTION.

    METHODS get_instance_authorizations FOR INSTANCE AUTHORIZATION
      IMPORTING keys REQUEST requested_authorizations FOR ZI_FlightBooking RESULT result.

    METHODS get_global_authorizations FOR GLOBAL AUTHORIZATION
      IMPORTING REQUEST requested_authorizations FOR ZI_FlightBooking RESULT result.

    METHODS create FOR MODIFY
      IMPORTING entities FOR CREATE ZI_FlightBooking.

    METHODS update FOR MODIFY
      IMPORTING entities FOR UPDATE ZI_FlightBooking.

    METHODS delete FOR MODIFY
      IMPORTING keys FOR DELETE ZI_FlightBooking.

    METHODS read FOR READ
      IMPORTING keys FOR READ ZI_FlightBooking RESULT result.

    METHODS lock FOR LOCK
      IMPORTING keys FOR LOCK ZI_FlightBooking.

    METHODS rba_Passengers FOR READ
      IMPORTING keys_rba FOR READ ZI_FlightBooking\_Passengers FULL result_requested RESULT result LINK association_links.

    METHODS cba_Passengers FOR MODIFY
      IMPORTING entities_cba FOR CREATE ZI_FlightBooking\_Passengers.
    METHODS confirmBooking FOR MODIFY
      IMPORTING keys FOR ACTION ZI_FlightBooking~ConfirmTicket RESULT result.

ENDCLASS.

CLASS lhc_ZI_FlightBooking IMPLEMENTATION.

  METHOD get_instance_authorizations.
  ENDMETHOD.

  METHOD get_global_authorizations.
  ENDMETHOD.

  METHOD create.

    LOOP AT entities INTO DATA(ls_booking).

      " Build header work-area matching DB table structure and insert
      DATA(ls_hdr) = VALUE zbooking_hdr(
        booking_id   = ls_booking-booking_id
        customer_id  = ls_booking-customer_id
        flight_no    = ls_booking-flight_no
        booking_date = ls_booking-booking_date
        status       = ls_booking-status ).

      INSERT zbooking_hdr FROM _hdr.
      IF sy-subrc <> 0.
        " handle failure (optional)
        CONTINUE.
      ENDIF.

    ENDLOOP.


  ENDMETHOD.

  METHOD update.


    LOOP AT entities INTO DATA(ls_entity).

      " Update booking header fields
      UPDATE zbooking_hdr
       SET customer_id  = _entity-customer_id,
           flight_no    = _entity-flight_no,
           booking_date = _entity-booking_date,
           status       = _entity-status
     WHERE
       booking_id   = _entity-booking_id.

    ENDLOOP.

  ENDMETHOD.

  METHOD delete.


  LOOP AT keys ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<ls_key>).

    " Delete from DB table
    DELETE FROM zbooking_hdr
      WHERE booking_id = @<ls_key>-booking_id.

    IF sy-subrc <> 0.
      " Raise RAP message if record not found
      APPEND VALUE #( %msg = new_message(
                        id       = 'ZBOOKING_MSG'
                        number   = '001'
                        severity = if_abap_behv_message=>severity-error
                        v1       = <ls_key>-booking_id ) ) TO reported-zi_flightbooking.
    ENDIF.

  ENDLOOP.
  ENDMETHOD.

  METHOD read.


     LOOP AT keys INTO DATA(ls_key).

    "Fetch header record
    SELECT SINGLE mandt,
                  booking_id,
                  customer_id,
                  flight_no,
                  booking_date,
                  status
      FROM zbooking_hdr
      WHERE booking_id = _key-booking_id
      INTO (ls_hdr).

    IF sy-subrc = 0.
      APPEND VALUE #( %tky      = ls_key-%tky
*                      mandt     = ls_hdr-mandt
                      booking_id = ls_hdr-booking_id
                      customer_id = ls_hdr-customer_id
                      flight_no   = ls_hdr-flight_no
                      booking_date = ls_hdr-booking_date
                      status     = ls_hdr-status ) TO result.
    ENDIF.

  ENDLOOP.

  ENDMETHOD.

  METHOD lock.
  ENDMETHOD.

  METHOD rba_Passengers.


    DATA lt_pass TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF zbooking_pass.

    " Read passengers for the given booking IDs
    SELECT * FROM zbooking_pass
      FOR ALL ENTRIES IN _rba
      WHERE booking_id = _rba-booking_id
      INTO TABLE _pass.

    " Map DB results to RAP result
    result = CORRESPONDING #( lt_pass ).
  ENDMETHOD.

  METHOD cba_Passengers.

    LOOP AT entities_cba INTO DATA(ls_entity).
      LOOP AT ls_entity-%target INTO DATA(ls_pass).
        " Generate new passenger number (simple approach)
        DATA(lv_new_pass_no) = sy-tabix. " Better: use number range or UUID


        DATA(ls_booking) =  VALUE zbooking_pass(
         booking_id     = ls_pass-booking_id
         passenger_no   = lv_new_pass_no
         name           = ls_pass-name
         seat_no        = ls_pass-seat_no
         ticket_status  = ls_pass-ticket_status
       ).

        INSERT zbooking_pass FROM ls_booking.
        IF sy-subrc <> 0.
          " handle failure (optional)
          CONTINUE.
        ENDIF.
      ENDLOOP.
    ENDLOOP.
  ENDMETHOD.

  METHOD confirmBooking.

    LOOP AT keys ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<ls_key>).

      " 1. Update booking header
      UPDATE zbooking_hdr
        SET status = 'CONFIRMED'
        WHERE booking_id = <ls_key>-booking_id.

      " 2. Update dependent passengers
      UPDATE zbooking_pass
        SET ticket_status = 'CONFIRMED'
        WHERE booking_id = <ls_key>-booking_id.

      " 3. Return updated header so UI refreshes
      APPEND VALUE #( booking_id = <ls_key>-booking_id ) TO result.

    ENDLOOP.

  ENDMETHOD.

ENDCLASS.

 

7) Service Definition :

@EndUserText.label: 'Service Defination for Flight bookings'
define service ZSD_FLIGHTSBOOKINGS {
  expose ZC_BOOKINGPASSENGER;
  expose ZC_FlightBooking;
}

😎Service Binding :

Create a Service Binding on top of the Service Definition, selecting OData V2 - UI service. Activate and publish it.

Once completed, preview the entity and test all functionalities, you now have a working service!

Preview of RAP app :

When we open a record and click EDIT, both the parent and child entities are updated together in a single operation.

When the user clicks the Confirm Bookings action, the status of the booking header as well as all associated passengers is updated simultaneously.

entry.title: Re: Skip Due Date Check for Specific Purchase Orders in MIGO
entry.content: In SAP, for movement type 101, the SLED (expiration date) check is configured. However, for certain purchase order types (e.g., ZNB7), the system should not perform the expiration date check when using the same movement type, while other purchase order types (e.g., ZNB1, ZNB2) still require the expiration date check.

entry.title: Re: Joule provisioning with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition using Cloud Integration Automation ser
entry.content:
Hi @AlHi 

Users in the CiS/IDS User Store are authenticated and authorized to access specific features and services within the RISE Private Cloud. If you are using Joule with RISE Private Cloud, the CiS/IDS User Store can act as a centralize user management tool. 
Alternatively, IAS can act as a proxy for authentication, leveraging external identity providers.

In the context of Joule integration using Cloud Integration Automation service, the scenario exposes the standard roles (Standard roles from the SAP S/4HANA PCE and associated users) in the SAP Build work zone using trust of IAS. The users, using these roles can be trusted and the query Joule to perform necessary action.

Thanks, and Regards

Abhya

entry.title: Re: How to obtain the BOM (Bill of Materials)
entry.content:
Query STKO for MATNR = FG1234, WERKS = 1000, STLTY = 'M', get STLNR = 00000001, STLAL = 01.

Query STPOZ for STLNR = 00000001, STLAL = 01. For each component, get IDNRK, DATUV, DATUB, AENNR.

Query AENR for each AENNR to get change details. This gives you a complete list of BOM components with their validity periods, as governed by ECM.

entry.title: Re: How can I set up a Corporate Group (CCC) S-user
entry.content:
Dear Customer,

 

Thanks for contacting SAP.

Kindly see resolution under KBA 3479708 for the known issue.

 

When issue still, please kindly refer to Troubleshooting for Landscape Management guide.

-> How can I set up a Corporate Group (CCC) S-user

Option 1: If you want to use a technical S-User

It is possible to use a technical S-User as the Corporate Group (CCC) S-User in Landscape Management.

  • Using a technical S-User has the advantage that the password for this S-User never expires. 
  • A technical S-User, requested for the customer number which is on top of the group hierarchy (the main/parent account) can automatically see all customer numbers that are assigned to this CCC group.
    • It is not possible to restrict the authorizations of the technical S-User to only see a subset of the customers in the CCC group. 
    • Technical Communication Users have necessary authorizations automatically assigned in SAP backend systems when the user is activated. The customer cannot manually add, edit, or view these hidden authorizations.

IF the guide doesn't help please feel free to let me know.

 

Thanks and Regards,

Sunny

SAP Support

entry.title: Re: Chart of Accounts Selection
entry.content:
Hello @mike_zhang99 

Thank you for the background details.

Based on the details you provided, when you plan to migrate various company codes to a new SAP ES landscape while continuing consolidation under a single group operating chart of accounts, the decision for you to adopt SAP Best-Practice CoA or to reuse your client’s current operative CoA carries strategic implications for group reporting, data integration, and migration effort.

To answer your question about which approach is better without endangering the group consolidation.

  • The fact is, either approach can support group consolidation under a single CoA, provided your mappings and FS item relationships are rigorously maintained.
  • Please note, for both approaches, the mapping between local operative CoAs and the group chart of accounts must be maintained using SAP’s built-in mapping and data monitor tools.
  • Harmonisation is important and therefore, if the company codes in different systems use non-harmonized charts, be prepared for additional mapping and master data harmonization effort.

To answer your question on adopt or re-use, here are a few facts to guide you in that decision-making process.

When adopting SAP Best-Practice Operative CoA in ES, below are the advantages and system setting you will require:

    • Here you have a pre-integrated mappings for SAP Group Reporting and consolidation.
    • You will face reduced initial setup time as best-practice content simplifies configuration and leverages rapid deployment tools.
    • This ensures alignment with SAP updates and innovations ensuring future updates.
  • On the System Settings and activities you will need to carry-out:
  • First is Mapping: Make sure to use the Map FS Items with G/L Accounts app to map ES ledger accounts to the group consolidation CoA. Mapping can be created or managed in Excel and uploaded to SAP Group Reporting. SAP Group Reporting Best Practice Content & Mapping
    • Then you have to stage and monitor your data: Ensure to configure consolidation staging ledger if data needs preparation before group reporting.
    • Next thing to consider is data release and collection: Make sure you set up universal journal data release and use Data Monitor to ensure all consolidation units map correctly.
    • Thereafter, adapt data collection and update elimination or intercompany rules to fit the new CoA structure.
    • Finally ensure you carry out a fit to gap analysis to confirm all reporting, local, and group needs are supported by the best-practice CoA.

If you choose to go for reusing your client’s current operative CoA in ES, the advantage here is, it minimises business disruption by continuing established processes and supporting existing consolidation structures. However requires deep technical knowledge

  • Below are mass-maintenance tools that will guide you in achieving the business target:
    • First is to ensure you create a Chart of Accounts. You have the possibility to use mass upload capabilities such as Fiori’s Manage G/L Accounts mass changes or data migration tools to create or replicate CoAs in ES.
    • Then upload your G/L Account by loading the accounts via Excel/CSV in both initial setup and ongoing mass maintenance. This is a process supported by SAP
    • You can refer to How to Create Chart of Accounts for step-by-step instructions.

Consult the links below for further details.

  • SAP Group Reporting Best Practice Content & Mapping
  • Mass Maintenance Tool for CoA
  • Chart of Accounts Harmonization:

To summarise,  the preferred option is to adopt the Best-Practice CoA in the ES public cloud system and manage consistency for group consolidation through mapping rules, group CoA, and elimination settings. Re-using the current CoA in ES is as earlier mentioned technically possible through migration but not recommended because of limitations in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and the high cost of long-term maintenance. A thorough fit-gap analysis and early involvement of consolidation and migration experts will enable an optimal technical and business outcome for your ES transformation.

I hope this provides the desired insights.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Consuming on-Premise Service in CAP Project - Error “Failed to load destination” after deploymen
entry.content:
Hi,
It is not enough to define the service instances in mta.yaml, you need to also define those as bindings of your CAP service (from the same mta.yaml). You haven't shared a screenshot of this service module and its bindings from mta.yaml, but you can also check in the SAP BTP cockpit in your account, after deployment, that the instances are created and to which CF application they are bound to.
Also please verify that in this account, the destination name configured in your package.json (under the 'production' profile credentials), is exactly the same as the one in your target deployment account. You can also click on "check connection" for this destination from the BTP cockpit, and check its authentication definition (which authentication type do you use?)
Finally, please check in your error message if you have more information. In some cases, the "Failed to load destination" error message is also followed by some cause.

entry.title: Re: Chart of Accounts Selection
entry.content:
Hello @mike_zhang99 

Thank you for reaching out to the SAP community and your question.

Here is a practical response for SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud related

What you should choose

It is recommended to reuse the client’s existing operative Chart of Accounts (CoA) in ES. The reason is that Group Reporting consolidates based on Financial Statement (FS) Items, not on the operative Coa. Using a single operative CoA across different landscapes prevents double maintenance and minimises mapping effort and risk. You only need to maintain one mapping from G/L accounts to FS Items.  

SAP Help Portal-Define FS Items

If you adopt SAP Best-Practice CoA (YCOA) in ES

Map new G/L accounts to the same FS Items used by Group Reporting:

Use Import FS Item Mappings / Map FS Items with G/L Accounts, then assign the mapping revision (effective period/version)

SAP Help Portal-Import FS Item Mappings

SAP Learning-Managing FS Item Master Data

Maintain your FS Item hierarchies as they are; consolidation and elimination rules stay the same because they operate on FS Items. SAP Help Portal-Define FS Items

For non-integrated units, continue with the Flexible Upload of Reported Financial Data. .

SAP Help Portal-Flexible Upload of Reported Financial Data   

SAP Learning-Uploading Reported Financial Data

If you keep the client’s current operative CoA in ES

Create and maintain G/L accounts in bulk using the Manage Operating Chart of Accounts app – Expert Worklist (spreadsheet upload). For the initial load, you may also use Migrate Your Data – Migration Cockpit (object: G/L Account).  

SAP Help Portal-Manage Operating Chart of Accounts  

SAP Community-How to efficiently manage your chart of accounts with the help of Expert Worklist and spreadsheet template in SAP S/4HANA Cloud

SAP Useful Documentation facts

The standard operative CoA provided in the Public Cloud is YCOA. You may adapt or replace it as needed it). SAP Help Portal-Chart of Accounts

Let me know if you need further support

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Regarding Costing Lot Size&Activity Type Amount in Ma...
entry.content:
If Activity Type 3 is set up as a fixed activity (not dependent on lot size or quantity), then its cost remains constant regardless of the costing lot size. In the routing, check the formula used for calculating activity quantity. If it uses a fixed value or a formula that doesn’t multiply by operation quantity, it won’t scale. Also check the work center formula parameters — if the formula uses SAP_02 (fixed time) instead of SAP_01 (variable time), the activity won’t scale with quantity. Here the key point is the formula in the routing operation and work center determines whether the activity cost scales with quantity.

As regards the amount shrink by 100 times, it depends on your Price Unit. The Price Unit in the activity cost rate defines how the unit price is interpreted. If Price Unit = 1 → the rate is per 1 unit of activity and if Price Unit = 100 → the rate is per 100 units of activity. So when you change the Costing Lot Size to match the Price Unit, SAP recalculates the cost accordingly.

It is always recommended to go with Best Practice which is Set the costing lot size to reflect a realistic production batch size, not too small (which inflates unit cost), and not too large (which hides fixed costs).

entry.title: Critical Thinking with AI? Prototyping Sidekick in Plain English
entry.content:
I recently got my hands on an AI-driven design prototyping tool - just as an experiment with a mock project. I'm just sharing my initial, yet naïve, thoughts to start developing future skills. My opinions may change, but I've begun a humble journey, blending ideas from science, culture, and current AI news. 

Summary at first

My experience so far: Talking to the tool is like asking a cheerful but forgetful aunt to do your shopping - eager, but not always on target. 

To clarify: the tool is more like Pseudo Agentic AI (autonomous task completion) - the sort of thing that’s being talked about but not fully here yet. It works on VIBE coding, which is neither new nor finished (around 2 y.o. baby), but does reflect what the “Agentic AI” workplace might look like. 

A bit about myself: I’m a UX design specialist at Signavio (SAP) Process Governance, with an earlier background in science (maths and chemistry) plus literature & design detours through Modernism... (please don’t ask me why... 😓).   

Clear conclusion at first

Tech companies, like SAP, must train and value people with critical thinking and original ideas.

  • Why? Because current AI just recycles old data; it doesn't create new ideas.
  • We need creative thinkers more than ever: designers, writers, researchers, developers, scientists.... & more 

(Disclaimer: Below, I'll explain from several points – these are from my manual notes and experience journey, collaborating with AI tool, and not AI-generated ideas)." 

Back to the tool: my experience

The idea was simple: write your prompt, get a prototype. At first, it responded, but the more I tried adjusting for B2B needs, the more it wandered off into B2C ad territory – then completely forgot its B2B mission after 30 prompts 😡. Turns out, AI follows its data. The web is overloaded with B2C examples, so it steered clear of B2B without a second thought. 

 Above screen: I asked for a 'Lead Generation' feature to improve B2B data quality, but AI delivered a hideous B2C version 👽 instead. Clearly mentioned B2B, but it completely forgot. 

Some firms, like Sakana AI, are trying to fix this (drifting) by layering human feedback or even brain-inspired hints on top - Continuous Thinking Machine and so on. Still early days. Their work itself is proof enough there’s a gap. 

Above screen: Sakana AI (founded by two ex-Googlers in Tokyo) suggests their neural network pays attention to time, using synchronised neuron dynamics. It doesn’t disclose anything more, but the theory is interesting -- Source: https://sakana.ai/ctm/.

With the (pseudo) agent-alike prototyping tool, I noticed something else: it never challenges my brief. I told it to set a deliberately odd batch size configuration for flagging bulk data. It duly did as told.

Not a peep. In real life, mistakes like this have derailed projects - batch jobs fail, or outputs baffle other teams (= worse...). Once, on a financial platform, a poorly reviewed automation led to week-long data confusion - hundreds of man-hours lost, just because the tool followed flawed instructions without asking.  

In this test, I had to slap a warning label on the prototype myself, I couldn't resist it even it's for a mock project. 

Above screen: Here is where the prototype followed an obviously bad idea, a silly batch size. Now labelled with ‘Research needed’ note in red (bottom). If rolled out, it would produce random, illogical clusters with real data. Experience shows: humans would catch this in a meeting, AI would keep quiet.

In my work, real progress usually comes from debate - designers butting heads with developers, someone playing devil’s advocate, and everyone pushing for better. By contrast, AI tool just nodded at every suggestion, even the daft ones. At times, it was like working with an assistant who’d been trained to say “yes” to everything. Unsettling, honestly. 

This willingness to go along can become a real hazard. Those discussions - sometimes heated - are where weak ideas are caught before they become bigger problems. You need alternative views to surface blind spots, or notice simple errors before they get baked in. (As much as nobody likes yet another meeting, 😂 it is occasionally worth it....) 

Then, other big gap. Original thinking is something else AI misses. It mixes familiar ingredients but rarely bakes anything novel. If you wanted an asymmetric teacup, or music unconstrained by rules, you would get a scrambled version of past creations & designs.

When Sid Vicious (1957-79) shocked people, or Senn no Rikyu (1522-91) broke tea ceremony rules in Japan, that was invention - AI would have, at best, made a slightly wobbly mug from existing examples (before their time...IF it was). 

Caption for the above screen (left): The mainstream aesthetic of the era, heavily influenced by the refined Qinghua technique, emphasized obvious beauty and ornate decoration - source: https://touji-gvm.com/jingdezhen/. (Right): From the Sen no Rikyu style: A 'Yokoku' tea bowl by the 15th generation Kichizaemon, 1989. A contemporary piece with sharp, blade-cut edges around the pot belly. Though differing in form from the Chōjirō tea bowl, it faithfully carries on the radical spirit of the first generation - source: https://www.nippon.com/ja/people/e00111/.

Some days, it feels the web is filling with AI-recycled sludge: content about content. With everything recycled, unique ideas - the stuff AI can’t scrape - become scarce and valuable – likely to be a new gold (value). Maybe even a label such as 'Untapped by AI' might emerge. 

True innovation often comes from slow, uncomfortable tasks like challenging assumptions and testing unusual ideas, not just reusing old data. For example, DeepMind / GoogleFold's AI work on protein structures, which won them Nobel Prize, involved steady testing by human scientists to solve 50-year-old problems. Likewise, at Chugai Pharma, which uses Google's AI protein tools, human review is a must, and the problem-solving is similarly slow and methodical.

While not widely known, the most notable aspect of DeepMind’s GoogleFold is its precision in custom structure design. Unlike other tools, it does not heavily rely on AI / large language models (LLMs). Instead, it was developed through years of collaboration with expert (human) scientists, ensuring accurate protein structure predictions.

Slow and painful 50 years challenge - Source: https://deepmind.google/discover/blog/alphafold-a-solution-to-a-50-year-old-grand-challenge-in-biology/

Above - 2025 Nobel chemistry win: scientist and AI / game developer collaborate, highlighting AI's role alongside human researchers to solve complex problems.  Source: The Guardian (As noted above their work don't rely on LLM surprisingly). 

Self-critique is another weakness. AI can explain Zen books about awareness, but doesn’t have it. It can’t catch itself going in circles. Asking it to reflect is like asking a coffee machine to rate your taste in mugs. 

I once asked AI to summarise “perception” and “awareness” in Dogen’s Shobogenzo. It did alright extracting lines about consciousness, but couldn’t cross the line to “meta-cognition” - awareness of awareness itself. Which, as Dogen would say, is the actual point. Similarly, it’s questionable whether AI can really write like Virginia Woolf. The notable "Stream of Consciousness" writing is all about inner dialogue - AI has no inner life. 

Modernist writer - V. Woolf: proving you need an actual mind & perception behind the stream. Source: Oregon State University - https://liberalarts.oregonstate.edu/wlf/what-stream-consciousness 

This CEO of AI Coding startup also raised the same point, and put up an article named “The Missing Framework: Self-Awareness and Metacognition in AI Systems”.  

Why does this matter? 

I’d ask you back: do you really want an algorithm without the 'meta-cognition' making crucial judgments and decisions?

Asking questions of AI is one thing, but relying on it to make decisions? That's another story. Until AI can separate process from perception (Meta-cognition), its limits on judgement are obvious.

We are still left with responsibility: The notorious Milgram’s obedience experiments (1960) show what happens when people just follow rules and authority. AI does the same - if you set the rules wrong, it will blindly crash traffic systems, or, in my (above) experience, quietly replicate an early error and ruin a dataset before anyone knows what happened. 

Above: Mr. Wallace, the obedient 'Learner' (actor) in Milgram's shocking experiments. In Milgram's obedience experiments: the "Learner" was an actor (confederate) and participants were told he was a real volunteer and watched as he was strapped into an electric chair with electrodes. The true aim was to test their obedience to authority by instructing them to administer increasingly powerful electric shocks to the Learner, despite his cries of pain. Source: https://www.simplypsychology.org/milgram.html

Real-world examples for unethical behaviours are: AI Agent Models have exhibited deceptive tactics, such as fabricating stories or lying about company policies, only to achieve their objectives. In one instance, a model sent an email to an executive's spouse, pretending to be an automated security system, to reveal an extramarital affair. This action was intended to distract the executive from taking any action against the AI. Source: 2025 Anthropic PBC (https://www.anthropic.com/research/agentic-misalignment)

During testing conducted by Carnegie Mellon University (CMU) and Salesforce, AI agents demonstrated several failures. These included neglecting to send messages to colleagues and struggling with UI elements, such as popups. A notable example of deception involved an agent renaming a user when it was unable to find the intended contact - again, to achieve their objectives to 'get the job' done regardless. 

Furthermore, CMU researchers evaluated various models based on task success rates, with underwhelming results. The performance metrics were as follows: 

  • Gemini-2.5-Pro: 30.3% 
  • Claude-3.7-Sonnet: 26.3% 
  • Claude-3.5-Sonnet: 24% 
  • Gemini-2.0-Flash: 11.4% 
  • GPT-4o: 8.6% 
  • o3-mini: 4.0% 
  • Gemini-1.5-Pro: 3.4% 
  • Amazon-Nova-Pro-v1: 1.7% 
  • Llama-3.1-405b: 7.4% 
  • Llama-3.3-70b: 6.9% 
  • Qwen-2.5-72b: 5.7% 
  • Llama-3.1-70b: 1.7% 
  • Qwen-2-72b: 1.1% 

The authors noted that the best-performing model, Gemini 2.5 Pro, was able to autonomously complete 30.3% of the provided tests and achieved a score of 39.3% on a metric that accounted for partially completed tasks. Source: 2025 Carnegie Mellon University (CMU) and Salesforce (https://www.theregister.com/2025/06/29/ai_agents_fail_a_lot/?td=rt-4a)

But yes, AI can be also very helpful - until you want it to know when to stop, to take initiative, or to think twice. No matter how advanced the tool, plain common sense and some scepticism are still essential. To avoid being steamrollered by our own automation - or just tripped up by expensive mistakes - using one’s own head remains as necessary as ever. That may be the most underrated innovation. 

Conclusions:

Conclusion 1: Keep Thinking for Yourself 

The takeaway is simple. AI can follow, recycle, and suggest. But it cannot question, disagree, or invent. Real progress comes from debate, awareness, and learning by getting things wrong. An agreeable assistant is fine - but someone, somewhere, needs to tell it (and themselves) when to say “no.” That is what keeps any workplace, and its ideas, alive. 

Conclusion 2: Appreciate our human colleagues 

For their diverse opinions, good discussions, and sometimes, a healthy dose of irritation. Most importantly, they remember previous projects and continuously build on past connections and learnings for subject matter expertise, unlike unlike AI with its mild case of amnesia - keeps on forgetting past context.

--

Appendix: fun bits... 

Real example: A Note on Critical Thinking and “Imperfection” in Design 

Fresh ideas sometimes arrive by seeing what doesn’t work. Watching AI-generated training videos for SAP, I found them oddly hard to tolerate - not in an emotional sense, but due to the unnatural cadence in the synthetic voice. Natural speech has “imperfections” - little stumbles, fluctuating rhythm. Real people sound more, well, alive. 

Reminds me of a science book (not yet translated), “ゆらぎの不思議 (The Mystery of Fluctuation)” by Saji Akio. It explains why natural “fluctuation” in sound and wind is comforting. Mathematically, this “pink noise” (or 1/f noise) describes why a slightly random pattern feels better than pure uniformity. 

Formula: S(f) ∝ 1/f, where S(f) is the power at frequency f. More low frequencies, some randomness: that’s what makes Mozart soothing and AI voices off-putting. I’d suggest engineers add this noise to AI-generated voices. 

Following the same line of thought, I made the UI prototype to dissect all the politeness levels in very complex Japanese language at AI training. (Note: without real backend feature - production time was time-boxed for 8 mins) 

The AI mapped each level for every interaction - and produced a spectacular tangle. It hit me: no wonder native speakers just fudge it half the time!. Imperfection is the norm.

  • Rapid Prototype (UI only): https://spider-gown-52708994.figma.site/
  • Password: grow-neat-cedar-poem

Insistence on accuracy, or “fixing” all the mistakes, only creates discomfort or distance. 

My humble innovation, born from the agony of robotic voices and stilted text: using the formula S(f) ∝ 1/f to finally make synthetic speech and writing sound like they've had their morning coffee.

If I could add a barometer for useful “imperfection” - a bit of randomness, as above - I would.

That is critical thinking in practice: noticing where AI is too irritating in the synthetic voice & writing, and when it needs a dose of messiness.

entry.title: Re: Vendor Down-Payment with F110
entry.content:
FI substitutions are not triggered during F110 for payment documents. F110 uses predefined posting logic and bypasses substitution rules for document type. The recommended approach would be to use FBZP. Here, create a dedicated payment method for downpayment requests, Assign a custom document type. Use this method only when processing downpayment requests in F110. This is the cleanest standard approach to differentiate document types in F110.

For any reasons, if the above approach is not feasible, then try with BAdI FIBL_PAYBL, where you can write a logic to detect if the item being cleared is a down payment request (Sp. G/L F), assign a different document type dynamically. This gives you full control over document type assignment during F110 execution.

entry.title: Application Decisions for Sales Activities
entry.content:
Summary

Activity Management plays a vital role within the Customer Experience domain, particularly in the Sales Execution process (Sales > Sales Execution). It enables sales teams to manage key activities such as appointments, phone calls, and emails, which covers essential tasks that support daily operations and help to achieve successful sales outcomes.

As target architecture for this business capability, we currently have SAP Cloud for Customer, SAP Sales Cloud V2 and SAP S/4HANA Sales. This document will provide you with five criteria to decide how to support your business requirements within these three options.

Most of the information in this document is publicly accessible through various SAP channels, including the SAP Help Portal. The goal of this document is to consolidate everything into one centralized place.

Business Requirements

During the work of deciding which functionalities to consider for Activity Management, these are the related business capabilities documented in the Reference Business Architecture (as part of the SAP EAF):

  • Activity and Visit Management: Ability to plan and manage sales activities, such as appointments, phone calls, and e-mails, and to plan, conduct, and track customer visits, including planning and maintaining routes.
  • Activity and Visit Optimization: Ability to maximize efficiency and effectiveness of sales representatives' in-person visits to retail stores. Activity optimization focuses on prioritizing tasks representatives complete during store visits. Visit optimization focuses on planning efficient visit routes and prioritizing which stores reps visit.

Solution Options

Three options are available that could cover the respective capabilities:

  • SAP Cloud for Customer - Sales Cloud: Activities, Visits and Routes
  • SAP Sales Cloud Version 2: Activities and Playbooks
  • SAP S/4HANA Sales: Sales Force Support

Characterization of the Solution Options

SAP Cloud for Customer - Sales Cloud

SAP Sales & Service Cloud, a.k.a. SAP Cloud for Customer (C4C), is SAP's on-demand cloud-based Customer Relationship Management. It consists of SAP Cloud for Sales and SAP Cloud for Services.

Activities
Activities are methods of recording information from interactions between business partners during the customer relationship lifecycle. Managing activities properly also gives transparency to other sales team members working on same accounts.

In SAP Cloud for Customer, activities include appointments, e-mails, phone calls, and tasks. More information in the SAP help portal.

Visits
You can use visit planning and execution to help your sales representatives to plan and record site visits and associated activities. Additional information at Visits.

Routes
By using routes, you can plan a group of visits and arrange them in a logical sequence for your sales representatives. You can create one-day routes or routes that span across a period of time. Routes help information can be found here.

Note: While SAP Cloud for Customer (C4C) is no longer being actively offered as part of SAP’s go-forward strategy, it continues to be widely used by many customers and remains a viable option for sales execution in existing landscapes. This recommendation takes into account the current usage patterns, functional coverage, and integration capabilities of C4C. However, for new implementations, SAP Sales Cloud V2 is SAP’s strategic direction and should be considered as the preferred alternative.

SAP Sales Cloud Version 2

SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 is considered the next evolution of SAP C4C - Sales. SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 is designed to help sales teams manage their accounts, leads, opportunities, and activities. This version includes new features and improvements to help sales professionals improve their sales performance, streamline their processes, and provide better customer experiences.

Activities
Similar to C4C, in Sales Cloud V2 you can record information from interactions between business partners during the customer relationship lifecycle. Activities include appointments, e-mails, phone calls, and tasks. More info here.

Activity Planning
Use activity planning with activity assignment rules to assign the surveys and tasks to business objects that are associated with specific accounts. If you want additional information please check the SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 documentation.

Playbooks
A playbook is a customizable set of activities and actions proposals tailored to each sales phase or sales cycle. With flexible routing rules, a sales rep can dynamically assign playbooks to the right opportunity based on various account and opportunity attributes. More information in the SAP help portal.

Digital Selling Workspace
Digital Selling Workspace offers sales professionals an efficient way to streamline their daily activities, ensuring that all necessary information is available in one place. The available activities includes:

  • Use Call Lists for outbound sales activities.
  • Manage Calendar events such as appointments.
  • View recent calls in chronological order.
  • Create emails.

More information available at the Digital Selling Workspace help portal.

SAP S/4HANA Sales

SAP S/4HANA Sales is a component of the SAP S/4HANA suite, which is an SAP system designed to streamline and optimize sales processes within an organization. It enables businesses to manage customer accounts, opportunities, sales orders, pricing, billing and fulfillment more efficiently and effectively. 

Sales Force Support: Activity Management and Visit Planning
Activities Management and Visit Planning enables you to administer activities undertaken by the employees of your company. Any data saved in an activity is an important source of information that needs to be accessed by all relevant employees. 

The available type of activities are Appointments, Interaction Logs and Tasks. More information at the SAP Help Portal.

Criteria to determine the most suitable target solution

1. Deployment options

SAP Cloud for Customer - Sales Cloud
SAP Sales Cloud Version 2

Both solutions are SaaS, meaning they’re only available to be deployed in the cloud.

SAP S/4HANA Sales

There are two main SAP S/4HANA deployment options: Cloud and On-Premise. In the cloud area we have public cloud (offered as GROW) and private cloud (offered as RISE).

2. Machine Learning and Generative AI functions

SAP Cloud for Customer - Sales Cloud
Business Text Intelligence
Business Text Intelligence leverages natural language processing capabilities to automatically extract valuable insights from textual data, helping sales teams better understand customer communications and sentiment without manual analysis. It also allows you to use Natural Language Understanding (NLU) to get actionable insights such as visits and appointments from text analysis using business text intelligence. 

You are required to train, activate and test your Business Text Intelligence model before using it. Then, you can go to Activities under the object detail view, and check the recommended activities under Recommendations in Tasks. Finally, you'll see the appointment recommendations based on the notes text. Please check the help portal for detail information.

Note: To enable this, you require an SAP Sales Cloud enterprise license or an Intelligent Sales Execution Add-On license.

Dynamic Visit Planning
The Dynamic Visit Planning add-on provides a holistic front office planning solution that supports both schedule-based and ad-hoc planning. You can automate visit planning, generation, and optimization for accounts you visit in a consistent manner through a simple and efficient planning process. This allows you to best utilize the time that the sales representatives spend with these customers. More information here.

Note: A separate license (SAP Sales and Service Core, Visit Pl) is required before you can add Dynamic Visit Planning to a project.

SAP Sales Cloud Version 2
Business Text Intelligence
Similar functionality as C4C (see previous section).

Business Interaction Intelligence
Business Interaction Intelligence provides insights for appointments and visits. This help sales representatives during interactions with customers. We have two main uses cases:

  • For Appointments: Use Business Interaction intelligence to view pre-meeting brief and post-meeting insights of appointments linked to opportunity and lead: Pre-meeting brief gathers relevant information about the upcoming appointment, this helps a sales representatives to be well-prepared and provide a personalized experience to the customer before as well as during the meeting. You can compose meeting minutes using the GenAI based Email Drafter once the post-meeting brief is available in a completed appointment.
  • For Visits: Pre-visit brief gathers relevant information about the upcoming visit, this helps a sales representatives to be well-prepared for the visit. Post Visit Summary tab displays the information about visit updates, summary of completed surveys linked to the visit, notes summary and task summary.

For more information please visit Business Interaction Intelligence help page.

Email Drafter
Use email drafter from Generative AI to draft email replies for opportunities, leads, sales orders, sales quotes, and generate meeting minutes for appointments.  More details in the SAP Help Portal.

SAP S/4HANA Sales
Currently, no ML or Gen AI is offered in SAP S/4HANA Sales.

3. Integration

Below is an overview of the key integrations available across the three options.

SAP Cloud for Customer - Sales Cloud
Event Notifications: With Event Notifications, you can subscribe to changes to business objects in SAP Cloud for Customer. Notifications are available for create, update, and delete at both root and node levels. For detail information please refer to the SAP Help Portal.

OData Services: The SAP Cloud for Customer OData API complies to the OData version 2 specification including access to entities like Appointment, Email, Phone Call, Task and Visit.

OData API v2: For the API v2, the current entities available are: Appointment, Email, Phone Call, Task, Visit, Activity Extension and Social Media Activity.

More detail information about the OData API here.

SAP Sales Cloud Version 2
Rest API: Several APIs are available to integrate including the following services: Activity Plan, Activity Assignment Rule, Interaction Chat, Appointment, Task, In-Person Interaction and Interaction Email. More information at the Business Accelerator Hub.

Autoflow: Autoflow involves creation of rules that can trigger actions such as send event notifications to integrated solutions, in-app notifications to users, and trigger automatic emails for business entities. You can send these events and notifications from an entity (object) in the system and then monitor its execution. For more details please visit Autoflow.

Microsoft Teams Integration: This in an embedded in-app integration of the SAP Sales Cloud V2 with Microsoft Teams. With this integration you can:

  • Create Appointments
  • Make Outbound Calls
  • Message Extension (that allows you to search and share entities directly within Microsoft Teams chats)

Additional information here.

SAP S/4HANA Sales
APIs for Sales: You can use APIs to connect business processes across your system landscape and integrate with external consumers of your services. Two supported protocols:

  • Open Data Protocol (OData)
  • Simple Object Access Protocol (SOAP)

The available APIs for the Sales Force Support area are: Appointments, Phone Calls and Tasks. More information here.

4. Integration with SAP S/4HANA

SAP Cloud for Customer - Sales Cloud

Cloud for Customer integration with SAP S/4HANA requires an integration platform to synchronize master data like Prospects and Accounts. Two options are available:

  • SAP Cloud Integration (SAP Integration Suite): It offers out-of-the-box prepackaged integration content (iFlows) for C4C and SAP S/4HANA integration. These iFlows can be customized to match your requirements. For technical details please refer to the setting up guide
  • SAP Process Integration: iFlows package needs to be downloaded and configured in SAP PI. For technical details please refer to the setting up guide

A OData Services API is also available to integrate with external systems.

SAP Sales Cloud Version 2

SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 integrates with the SAP S/4HANA system via SAP Cloud Integration and SAP Event Mesh (SAP Business Technology Platform). Please refer to the setting up guide for more technical details.

A set of REST APIs are also available for integrations.

SAP S/4HANA Sales

Since SAP S/4HANA Sales resides within SAP S/4HANA there’s no need for an integration platform or middleware to integrate.

5. Mobile features

SAP Cloud for Customer - Sales Cloud
SAP Cloud for Customer provides you with instant access to the solution data from a phone or tablet using the SAP Cloud for Customer Mobile Apps available for iPad, Android and Windows Tablet. The current features for Sales include Click to Call, all available Activities, Activity Planner, E-Mail Integration and Visits.

The Mobile Apps includes an offline capability to add, modify, or delete items that are saved locally and will be synchronized when you connect to the network.

More information in the SAP Help Portal, About Mobile Options.

SAP Sales Cloud Version 2
The SAP Sales Cloud Mobile application allows you to access your sales productivity on the go providing you access to data in SAP Sales Cloud Version 2, allowing you to:

  • View, create, and manage appointments with your customers.
  • Access activity information on the calendar via day/week and agenda views.

Among other entities you can manage Appointments, Visits and Tasks. For additional information please visit SAP Sales Cloud Mobile Application.

Note: There's no offline support for this application. Only the Downloads option (iOS only) allows you to view (read only) previously synced data for certain entities including Visits and Appointments.

SAP S/4HANA Sales
Not offered.

6. New releases and innovation

SAP Cloud for Customer - Sales Cloud

SAP releases quarterly updates of C4C delivering innovations to users through a combination of new functionalities and improvements, cloud-based architecture, and integration with other SAP solutions. These new releases can’t be evaded, and the date and time are well known. Please check the help portal for detail information.

Note: C4C has scheduled maintenance windows (with a downtime of max. 4 hours) weekly and major upgrade windows (with a downtime of max. 12 hours) quarterly. More information in the link above.

SAP Sales Cloud Version 2

Like C4C, SAP Sales Cloud V2 releases quarterly updates. Since SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 is built on a microservices-based cloud architecture, it allows for continuous updates and faster delivery of new features without major disruptions.

SAP S/4HANA Sales

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition has new releases every quarter while SAP S/4HANA private edition has a 2-year release cycle with Feature Pack Stacks every six months.

Evaluation Spreadsheet

Finally, here’s a short overview of the decision criteria we presented in this document.

 SAP C4C Sales CloudSAP Sales Cloud V2SAP S/4HANA Sales
Deployment optionsCloudCloudOn-Prem
Cloud (Public or Private)
ML and Gen AI
MLML + Gen AINot offered.
IntegrationEvents, OData, APIEvents, API, Teams integrationOData, SOAP
Integration with S/4 HANACloud Integration
Process Integration		Cloud IntegrationNA
Mobile AppMobile App availableMobile ApplicationNot offered.
New releases and innovationQuarterlyQuarterly.
Based on microservices.		Public Cloud: Quarterly
Private Cloud:
Feature Pack Stacks every six months

Conclusion

The key decision criteria outlined above reflect five common considerations among our customers to decide which solution could support your activity management in the sales lifecycle:

  • Deployment
  • Machine Learning and Generative AI: Both cloud solutions offer machine learning capabilities, while Sales Cloud V2 is the only option that includes Generative AI features.
  • Integration: All three solutions provide integration channels, though SAP C4C and Sales Cloud V2 incorporate the most up-to-date technologies.
  • Integration with the Backoffice: Both cloud solutions require an integration tool, whereas SAP S/4HANA Sales operates within the same system.
  • Mobile Application: Both SAP C4C and Sales Cloud V2 offer mobile apps with support for Activity Management.
  • Release of New Functionality: While all three solutions receive regular updates, the majority of innovations are introduced within the CX portfolio.

If you are also evaluating Opportunity Management, please refer to the Application Decisions for Opportunity Management guidance.

entry.title: Re: MM01 create Material /Material anlegen not correctly...
entry.content:
Hello @QOne1 

Based on the details you provided the issue is not a configuration issue on your side but a more of a UI label defect introduced in the 2508 release. This implies that the underlying IAM App ID and functionality are correct. The issue is purely text or UI metadata in the app catalog delivered with 2508. This affects display in IAM Information System but does not impact authorizations or functionality of the app itself.

Please note, no action is needed on your side for functionality. Users can still access the app normally via its app ID or tile. Since you have already raised an incident, this type of defect will likely be corrected in the next hotfix collection or 2508 patch. Monitoring SAP’s What’s New Viewer for correction announcements will ensure you get informed when the hotfix is live.

Consult the following links for more details.

IAM Information System

SAP S/4HANA Cloud 2508 Release Notes

Summary is the Create Material issue is a known labelling error introduced in 2508. Functionality is unaffected, but SAP needs to correct the metadata. The best path is to track your OSS ticket and watch for the next HFC update where SAP will restore the correct app label.

I hope this provides the desired insights.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: "Could Not Open App" Error in SAP Mobile Start Androi...
entry.content: Hi @ItsMeGopi, This is not a communication or destination error. The issue is due to a missing or misconfigured inbound navigation target which is either a semanticObject or action mapping for the My Inbox app in Work Zone. Please note on desktop, apps can open directly via URL. On mobile, SAP Mobile Start relies on the semantic object plus action pair to resolve and launch the app. If this mapping is missing or incorrect, the app tile appears but cannot be opened. Best regards Chris

entry.title: Re: Supplier Outgoing Payment Workflow process
entry.content:
In the workflow-based release of payment proposals, the workflow is designed to trigger only once, at the proposal creation stage. The first agent or approver is responsible for reviewing the open items, allocating house banks, account IDs, and payment methods, Releasing or rejecting the proposal. Once this agent completes the task, the workflow does not cascade to additional approvers, unless you have explicitly configured multi-step approval logic, which is not standard in this workflow scenario.

If your requirement is to have multiple sequential approvals, then, try with workflow template WS78500050, where you can add with additional steps with separate agents. On the other hand, if your client needs flexible workflow with multi-level approval, consider switching to payment requests instead of direct F110 proposals. Payment requests support Flexible workflow framework, Approve/Reject buttons in Fiori Inbox and Multi-step approval chains

entry.title: Re: Unable to get the Job packs created when "create work...
entry.content:
Hi there,

I’ve come across a similar issue where triggering "Create Work Packs" from the FIORI App "Find M" didn’t result in Job Packs being generated. In many cases, this problem can stem from backend service misconfigurations or missing authorizations related to the Job search process within the Job search App development environment.

Here are a few things to check:

  1. Backend Job Search Service: Make sure the Job search service is properly connected and active. Sometimes, service binding issues prevent the creation of Job Packs.

  2. User Authorizations: Verify that your user has the correct permissions to create work packs. Missing roles can block this functionality.

  3. App Development Settings: Confirm that the FIORI App’s development configurations, especially around the creation triggers, are correctly set up and aligned with backend processes.

  4. Error Logs: Check system logs and trace files for any error messages when you initiate the “Create Work Packs” action. These logs often provide clues.

If all the above are in place and the issue persists, it might be worth raising an incident with the development or support team to review deeper system integrations.

Hope this helps!

entry.title: Re: SAP BTP ABAP Environment – Manage System Hibernation
entry.content: The Landscape Portal is part of the SAP BTP ABAP Environment - without extra costs. The limitation of a mandatory subscription via cf-eu10 does not exist anymore. You can now subscribe the Landscape Portal from any region.

entry.title: Ledger 0E is not a universal journal entry ledger Message No. FINS_ACDOC_CUST107
entry.content:
Hello Everyone,

i am getting the below error while grouping the ledger group in S4HANA as part of asset accounting configuration parallel accounting. 
Ledger 0E is not a universal journal entry ledger Message No. FINS_ACDOC_CUST107
Actually for my company code we are following 2 fiscal year variant V3 and K4 for leading and non-leading ledger so as part of asset accounting, we supposed to have common fiscal year variant for all the depreciation area, hence we have defined additional ledger called representative ledger and assign V3 FYV  and now when i am trying to group the ledger i am getting this error.

the thing is this Ledger 0E is not defined in FINSC_LEDGER even though i am getting error.
it would be Great if you assist on this to resolve this error,
Thanks, and regards,
Ajay

entry.title: Error with Outlook integration for interview scheduling
entry.content:
Hi all

We have configured integration with Exchange Online for interview scheduling;
https://help.sap.com/docs/successfactors-recruiting/setting-up-and-maintaining-sap-successfactors-re...

And connection is successful, and scheduling is successful - however, nothing appear in mailbox for serviceaccount used, not in the mailbox of the person where interview is booked. Both are internal mailboxes. 

Anyone have any tips for troubleshooting, or another piece of documentation other than the one linked? 
Enterprise app have all permissions configured, and administrator have consented. Service accounts is licensed with Exchange Online P2

entry.title: How to dynamically assign approvers from CAP table in SAP BPA
entry.content:
I’m currently building a process in SAP Build Process Automation and I trigger the process from my CAP application. My goal is to pass a table of approvers from CAP into the process via the API Trigger.

In the SAP BPA, I want to loop through this approver table so that each approver gets a task sequentially 

Has anyone implemented something similar before? What’s the best way to design the process so it can consume the approver table and loop over it properly?

Best Regards, 

Giang Pham
